review_title: Invest in some Integrity - Support your adjuncts
job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Talented, smart, inquisitive, and creative students. Strong performing arts training programs (especially the BA Acting/Directing program). PPA is in touch with trends within the performing arts. Faculty and PPA administrators genuinely care about the students and are doing good work.
cons: Adjunct pay is among the lowest of all NYC universities. There is no job security. Both the pay and academic standards are lower than at other universities in the area. If a student has an issue with a professor, the Pace admin sides with the student because they want the tuition money. Management and admin are afraid of the students and lower the standards to protect their jobs.

job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros: There are many reasons to like Pace, including the student body, and there is a certain amount of freedom. Can propose new classes almost as much a you want.
cons: The university has been in dire financial circumstances for many years, pre- and during Covid, and can't seem to get out. Raises are hard-found, infrequent, and stingy. Many dissatisfied faculty. Empty offices, most faculty still teach online. A equity initiative passed by faculty 2 years ago was not funded by administration, leaving many people bitter. There is an overall lip service approach to diversity and inclusivity issues for students, faculty, or staff, and if you are at all concerned about this look elsewhere. It is a disappointing place.

cons:
-HUGE disparities in top earners in administration and pay for faculty / staff
-Senior admin does not listen to faculty / staff 
-A lot of staff vacancies and turnaround - people are not paid living wages and so the best move on, leaving fewer people with unmanageable work loads
-very high tuition for students, meaning many students work unsustainable hours / take out large loans - faculty have to be cognizant of not assigning too much work

job_title: Academic Coach in New York, NY
pros: Pay was actually decent especially since I started with not much experience. Working with students and genuinely doing something that is helping students achieve the utmost academic success which is a rewarding feeling! Free graduate tuition for full-time employees, you get your own office so that you can best work with students.
cons: Management and office culture need improvement there's a lack of communication, they criticize and leave no room for work-life balance, meaning they made me decide between work and personal obligations like my sister's wedding. Human resources did not help as I was in the process of resigning, they completely let me down at the end of the day. I also always felt like they treated me like I owed them something. Pace University in general can be disorganized, you never know who to contact for specific issues, and you almost never get a response back.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Generally speaking, its not a bad place to work.  The hours for most employees are minimal (35 to 40 hours per week) and the vacation time allowance is very generous -above most corporations or private businesses.  The benefits (health care, dental, vision, 403b, etc.) are on par with most corporations and / or private businesses.  There are definitely some pockets of people in the university that are bright, hardworking and dedicated to the university and doing a great job for students.
cons: Low pay and limited opportunity to advance.  In my experience, many people are there just putting in their time.  I've seen a lot of unqualified people in positions they don't belong in across too many departments and / or schools within the university.  There's a lack of accountability in many instances.   The university has not been doing well financially for several years. To be clear, it appeared the university pulled out of the financial crisis it was in a few years ago only to re-emerge once again in financial crisis.   There are budget freezes, hiring freezes, selling off of real estate to meet financial obligations.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Lots of days off, flexible time off during the summer, beautiful office space
cons:
Where to start...the Executive Management in Career Services is awful; they don't care about staff, only promote "yes" people and take advantage of hard working staff. The people that management has hired to replace former key employees are laughable. They have no real management experience or just got promoted because they don't question what's happening in the office. In one year, 22 staff members have left or gotten fired for no reason (over 50 years of experience) and this is good news according to management. 

The people who are left are desperately looking to leave or are so despondent that they just clock in and clock out. There is no real incentive for employees to give their all and students are the ones who suffer. The focus has shifted from helping students to just counting placements. Overall, the level of disrespect that is given to hard working employees from upper management is alarming. There are no real opportunities to advance, unless you want to be a "yes" person and leave your integrity at the door. Awful pay, unless you are one of the aforementioned "yes" people. They are the ones who are cashing in while entry level staff are making $5-7K less than what they would make at other universities.

review_title: Not Worth the Stress of Dealing with Discriminating Management
job_title: Administrative Assistant in White Plains, NY
pros: Working at the Pace Women's Justice Center at Pace school of Law is in a way a rewarding experience when you believe in the cause because you are helping Victims of Domestic Violence. The University benefits are excellent.
cons: Little money a lot of stress by management.  Certain Management individuals  that work there are controlling and treat staff worse than the victims themselves have been treated. They choose and pick the clients that they will be helping, for an organization that is non-profit you see discrimination at it's best and when you stand up for yourself you get fired. Administration and Human Resources supports this kind of behavior the discrimination is targeted to Blacks and Latinos. I never saw a Jewish or other considered white individual being fired but they are promoted very quickly. I don't think that the Board Members, Funders, Donors or People in County Office are aware of this happenings and if they are aware then Shame on them. If you are Latino or Black think twice before working for this organization salaries are low and no opportunities for advancement.

review_title: If you don't care about growth in your profession and want a cushy job, this place is for you!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Unlimited sick days. Two weeks vacation + holidays
cons:
A good chunk of your whole department will talk behind your back. Your manager will not lead their team, help you grow or give you credit for what you have done. If you are extremely sick and have a doctor's note, be prepared to be reprimanded for being out. And your yearly reviews—your manager will not write themselves—they will have someone else in your department write it for them. 

To be honest, my whole experience working at Pace, I have been yelled at for doing my job and caring about the quality of work that I put out. I would be told to do one thing and get yelled at a few weeks later for doing it. I would help out my neighbor with some of his workload, only to find him working on other projects for different company's or shoe shop online.

* Just keep in mind that this was my experience in my department. Other departments might be different, so take this for what it is.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Not much at all good about working there.
cons: Very low pay for a lot of work. Management was poor and unkind and seemingly incompetent. Was waiting to leave.

review_title: Great place to start, poor place for long-term employment
job_title: IT Department in New York, NY
pros:
- Great for starting a new profession and recent college grads especially in IT.
- Free undergrad tuition for self, spouse and children. Only pay for taxes.
- Discounted Masters program.
- Lots of vacation days.
- Full benefits while not great are at least offered here. Medical, dental and vision. 401k and retirement plans.
- Laid back environment.
- Paid training although it must be relevant to your current job title.
cons:
- Very low compensation, 30-40% less than average of area.
- Long hours with no overtime compensation. Expect to work on weekends and holidays.
- Little room for advancement unless moving to another dept.
- Poor project planning. Lots of last minute work due to poor implementation of strategy. 
- Lots of micro management from managers. Always feels like you're about to lose your job.
- Too many meetings and meetings about meetings.
- Apathetic managers who only care about their position.

review_title: Pace University: where no good deed goes unpunished.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Paid time off is okay.
cons: Are you an employee who loves to take initiative and go the extra mile? Then prepare to be used and abused here at Pace, where the better you are at your job, the more work you're given - just don't expect to be compensated for it. Or to be promoted. Ever. Over the past year in my current role, I have steadily been given more and more responsibilities outside the scope of my job description and pay grade, to the point that I now literally have triple the workload I signed on for. Any time I've asked about a raise, I've literally been laughed at by my supervisor. And my job description has never officially been changed. This holds true for the majority of the people in my department, and my friends in other departments across campus. So I, and most of my colleagues, have settled for the "do just enough to not get fired" approach to working as we desperately search for new jobs. And don't bother going to HR - they're either corrupt or completely incompetent. The jury's still out on which.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasantville, NY
pros: The past couple of years in particular were filled with change in the University and Career Services. These changes presented challenges and opportunities and for me, growth. I received a title change/promotion after years of being at the same title/level. I also had an opportunity to develop processes, implement new programs and work closely with a School and its Deans, something that was previously "reserved" for management level. The time off policy is very  generous, as is the  the 403b and the location was great for me. Overall my colleagues in the department were professional, supportive and reliable. I had opportunities to collaborate with other departments and to teach.
cons: There is a lot of change, which some people don't like. Higher ed in general is much more focused on outcomes and numbers, this is not special to Pace, this is the way the industry is going.

review_title: It was good place to gain some experience on resume
job_title: Desktop Technician in New York, NY
pros:
-Get to work downtown by South Street Seaport if you are in the NYC campus.
-Staff can be pretty friendly.
-Tuition reimbursement is great if you wish to get a degree.
-Lots of vacation time. 15 days starting off I think and it accrues up to 21 each year. Unlimited sick time so long as it's not abused.
-Room for career growth within university due to high turnover.
-Good place to gain some work experience on resume.
cons:
-Gets super busy in September and January when students come back.
-High turnover for employees because they simply don't pay very well. Executives and directors get to sign contracts for lots of money which leaves the actual employees who make the university run with very little money.

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Occasional nice and capable people, who would soon be disenfranchised, and either assimilated into the culture of inaction, or without much choice, leave the institution eventually.
cons: An institution that dreams mildly high, has a vivid case of low self-esteem, and is still in the process of finding out the differences in what it wants to do and what it can do.  And like most not so successful organizations, underpays its talents, and provide even less room for growth, that it effectively trains talents for other organizations.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Campus is expanding, great students, good facilities.
cons: I work full time in industry and teach 1 or 2 classes at Pace a year. My adjunct per credit rate has not increased in over 5 years. I used to teach here for the pure joy of it. Money was never the motivation, however; it has gotten to the point where the rate I receive as an adjunct (after taxes less than $2,000 per course), barely covers my travel expenses. Because of this I unfortunately decided to discontinue my association with Pace (with regret).

job_title: in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Benefits are decent especially if you have kids as there are full tuition benefits.
cons: Horrible environment, as a full time employee I've seen rampant affirmative action violations, many were told to high ranking people who run things, but did nothing or swept them under the rug. No incentive to share issues with management in fact you risk being seen as a troublemaker if you do. Too many people who went to Pace stay and work at Pace, no new ideas come in, and Pace is decades behind other schools in its programs and degrees.  Too many employees and faculty stay for 20+ years and don't move aside or stay up to date. Academically low standards, good enough to get by but no one excels.

review_title: Fantastic Opportunity for Growth as a Student
job_title: Pace Abroad Leader
pros:
-Some of the most wonderful mentors you could ask for!
-You learn a lot about different policies and procedures for International Students outbound and incoming applications, different options for financial aid, and the amount of resources offered by all of our institutions. 
-Get an end-year performance review that really helped propel my growth in the working world.
-Had an end-year celebration at my managers house where all of the graduates of 2017 received a resume holder, business card holder, and laser-engraved pen.
-Opportunity to lead presentations and speak with educational administrators from all of our international partners!
cons: -Last minutes things crop up which leads to staying later but that's to be expected. No real downsides.

job_title: Student Aide in New York, NY
pros: They have great benefits and pay for my education. My direct supervisor is understanding and trustworthy.
cons: There is zero room for professional growth unless you have been in one position for multiple years. The managers are sneaky and abusive to the employees. They don't give credit for work done by staff. Employees are over worked and get paid very little compared to other universities. Managers claim that there is an open door policy but as soon as you come with an issue or feedback you are either shot down or written up. Staff members are frequently not properly trained on all work duties and then thrown into situations were they are bound to fail.

review_title: needs a lot of help, tolerant of people abusing their positions
job_title: Assistant Professor in New York, NY
pros:
There is an overall general interested in improving their degrees, and an openness to developing interdisciplinary programs.

The students are really quite good.
cons:
Unqualified people in high ranking jobs. 

Senior administrators do not enforce employment rules, many faculty abusing their positions to hire friends.   

Facilities feel neglected, which is improving slightly with high profile new construction, but clearly needs to happen more comprehensively. 

Competition between departments and campuses prohibits growth and confuses students.

review_title: Review of Adjunct Appointment at Pace University
job_title: Adjunct Professor Professor in New York, NY
pros: Adjuncts were given complete freedom with regard to choice of text, number of exams, course structure, etc.  Students were for the most part interested in college studies. Yearly review of performance was based on an evaluation done by fellow faculty member who visited my class for 1 hour.
cons: Teaching was almost in a vacuum-no faculty meetings and very little opportunity (besides 1 hr yearly evaluation) to interact with other members of the department.  Students were mixed--some very interested and motivated, but others were immature, talked in class, did not ask questions, came late, etc.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Adjuncts can be more involved in the University than at other colleges.  Faculty and staff and even administrators can be very welcoming and interested in collaborating. The University has many excellent resources available to adjuncts, including workshops, conferences and cultural events.
cons: An adjunct is an adjunct is an adjunct.  No job security, minimal benefits.  Can't survive on adjunct pay here or anywhere.  Doesn't really move career forward as there is no pay for research/writing.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Nothing I found as pros (may be this is in NYC that's all). Transportation to the Winchester campus is horrible.
cons: Very poor pay. They said tuition is free for full-time staff, but they imposed too much fee and tax on it; that is about one-third of tuition you have to pay extra. Health care premium is very expensive. If you have family, don't even think about buying health insurance from Pace. They increase the premium 5% every year. End of year salary increase is 1%-2% only. Where higher education industry average is about 4% and private sector is about 6%. Worse management! Had to work for on average of 10-12 hours a day in busy season (extra work for the lowest pay). There is no business process. Extremely high termination rate! When I joined first, almost every month someone was fired or did resignation. Only the people work here who have no options. I would give it a zero if possible.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: It is really hard to find a Graduate assistant position at Pace. You need to approach professors and different offices such as OSA, HR. I worked at OSA as a Data Analyst at Pace. The work as really good, I learned a lot of skills. The most important benefit that I got is I didn't have to pay tuition fees for my Master's degree as I was a Graduate Assistant.
cons: If you have already had a professional experience working in IT, then you will not like the work culture. Work culture is not that bad but it's not as free as it is in IT companies but I guess that's expected considering this is an educational institution.

job_title: Programmer in New York, NY
pros: It is a friendly work environment where no ever ever gets laid off and I've never seen someone even be fired. Cozy place to work. Great benefits. I'd you enjoy being poor and having the same exact job duties until you dir, then this is the place for you.
cons: Staff can be unprofessional. If you went to a business school as I did, steer clear. Low pay. Behind the times. Only work here if you have no drive to do anything better. Great for lazy people that never want to work hard.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Summers are very slow, and no one cares if you walk out the door right at 5 p.m. on the dot.
cons:
Pay is terribly low, and even "merit" increases are insulting. Two percent of nothing is still nothing.

There is no room for growth. They give promotions sometimes, but they seem to be in title only. Many staff members have been at the university for decades and plan to stay forever, so there's nowhere for new employees to go.

Total lack of forward thinking. New initiatives are summarily rejected, there is no flexibility in annual budgets to pivot, and employees who haven't been around for many years are routinely overlooked and not valued as staff members or as people.

job_title: Department Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Work-life balance, lots of time off due to the school holidays, and everyone is out the door at 5 pm
cons: Salary is way below market rate. No upward mobility unless you have an advanced degree. Very bureaucratic structure. Folks that work there have been doing the same job for over 20 years and lack efficiency and innovation.  The tenured faculty do not respect support staff and power trip which may include demeaning behavior that in another setting would be deemed as bullying and racist.

review_title: I have been a full-time and adjunct Associate Professor of Education for  many years.
job_title: Adj Associate Professor in New York, NY
pros: Pace U. has been an innovative, congenial and intellectually-stimulating environment.  Colleagues, administrators, students and support teams, such as the Ed Media Department, the Curriculum and Instruction Technology Lab and the Library are of the highest quality.  Working with these individuals is a perfect place for all involved to feel  secure and to make progress in their chosen fields.
cons: I have nothing negative to say about this institution.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Unlimited sick time, decent benefits packages available, desirable location in Manhattan, sadly not enough pros to meet the 20 word minimum.
cons: Frequently absent management getting paid over inflated salaries, with hard working employees being grossly underpaid even for cost of living standards. Development has no direction and wildly creates events and projects which are costly and generate very little donations. Seem to be very money focused regarding the students but never have money to augment the faculty.  Slightly delusional about their footprint and reasons why students choose Pace.

review_title: Has it's perks but culture. morale and management have declined
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: There is an amazing sense of community here at the University.  It can be a fun environment and as someone in IT, we are always implementing fun technology to move the University forward.  There is job security, yearly raises, and work flexibility.  There are good benefits (vacation time, medical, retirement plan, etc) and there is always something new to work on.  I am constantly learning which is something that I love.  It keeps the job fresh!
cons: Because of the job security, there is almost a 'tenure' when it comes to staff.  This can cause issues where some staff become lazy because they know they won't be let go easily.  Also, because of Faculty Tenure, we have faculty who should no longer be teaching, but cannot be fired.  We have lost a lot of students and revenue because of this and administration isn't making the best choices with the money we do have.  What was a University that excelled is now a University that's trying to do what everyone else does... not exactly exceptional anymore.  There are people who love the University and have worked here many years but are not being compensated, promoted, and are not getting credit for work done.  We get more work and more work, with not even a thank you.  There is no appreciation for the staff or the work that gets done, especially when we are making the University money.

job_title: in New York, NY
pros: You get to work with and meet some genuinely great people. Benefits (free tuition, 403B, events, etc.) and the staff you work with are the only redeeming qualities.
cons: Management is decades behind the times. No risks (other than building up an expensive campus) are taken to advance the school because everyone lives in fear of being thrown under the bus by management. Higher-ups are lazy and out of touch. The culture in every office and department is vastly different. Things seem very unfair throughout campus.

review_title: Great place to start your career, but get out as soon as you feel you have a strong foundation.
job_title: Admission Counselor in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Able to learn many aspects of this position, good place to get your foot in the door to gain knowledge and experience.
cons: Salaries are very very low, yearly raises are minimal or non-existent, and do not reflect even the cost of living for the area. Management, while they may have excellent goals and ideas, have little to no interaction or concern for the "underlings". Though the vacation and benefits package is decent, good luck trying to use it all. Though it is not necessarily always difficult to take vacation/personal days, you will often be made to regret doing so. Communication is poor at the university overall, everyone is out for themselves and always trying to pass the buck to someone else. Overall, the University seems to be improving in some areas, such as customer service and dependability, but as a fellow reviewer stated, it is unclear whether management values its experienced employees, or would rather replace them with new grads that they can pay a minimal salary.

review_title: Okay job for students with work study
job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The university us accommodating to work around student schedules, however, hours have been significantly cut due to lack in funding which is understandable. Students used to be able to work up to 20 hour weeks during the school year and up to 35 hours during breaks, but that is no longer the case in 2020. Students are better off finding an off-campus job or internship during the school year that pays a bit more and allows more hours.
cons: Menial tasks for a student depending on the department you work for.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Pace has a great work environment, comraderie, opportunities for growth and learning. The faculty is smart and responsive to each other and to the students. Also, the location of Pace University is great in NYC, and the students are motivated, diverse, and eager to learn. Many students are first generation college students.
cons: Not a lot of information sharing among faculty. Everyone does their own thing and is not closely monitored by the department chairs. Not a lot of use of educational technology.

job_title: Program Coordinator in Pleasantville, NY
pros: There is a great work life balance. Really great environment to work in. The tuition remission is a really nice perk for working here. The benefits are excellent. There is a lot of room for growth and opportunity if you're a hard worker. The staff and faculty here are for the most part really friendly and always willing to help you out if you need it.
cons: How much you enjoy your job really depends on the department you're in and who your boss is.

review_title: Rewarding experience and tons of amazing people but watch out for some bad apples
job_title: Pace Graduate Assistantship in Pleasantville, NY
pros: The office culture is very relaxed and there is a good work life balance. Personal growth opportunities are there if you are proactive and make the right connections within your Pace University network.
cons: There are some people who are unqualified, unethical, vindictive and untrustworthy working there. So look out for them and try to avoid having tasks that cross their paths.

review_title: Computer resource Center - ITS - Student Assistant
job_title: Graduate Student Staff Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great experience to attached to your resume (Experience is needed for any job nowadays)
cons: The pay is not that great. Student assistant positions are paid hourly, and at a very low almost minimum wage rate for shifts that are less than the part time that is entitled at the beginning. That in a city like New York (less than 1k/month is just not sufficient.)

review_title: Didn't know how dear it was to me until I transferred
job_title: Chemistry Lab Tech in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Small class sizes, research and internship opportunities, student job opportunities, helpful advisers and friendly staff, excellent location on both campuses, good transportation systems, a great student community, a ton of student events and clubs
cons: The tuition is too high, they tend to add on fees at the end that have to be paid out of pocket

job_title: Coordinator in Pleasantville, NY
pros:
A great place if you like a challenge.
Can make a difference in young people's lives with people who care.
Can earn up to 5 weeks vacation, plus holidays, plus personal days, plus 8 hours release time for community service for full time staff.
Break on tuition for you, spouse or dependents (undergraduate and graduate).
cons:
Pays less than other sectors
Disparities between lower and and upper administrative/faculty salaries (but hey isn't that everywhere?)
Is diverse, but could be more diverse.

job_title: Associate Director of Admission in New York, NY
pros: Tools, technology and resources to do your job. Professionally supportive. From first day of employment 22 vacation days + the week between Christmas and New Year's off as another paid week vacation.
cons: New upper management in division is not supportive and does not create the sence of "team" and camaraderie that there used to be. Only received advancement in salary after HR reviewed salary levels and evaluations compared to others in similar positions both at Pace and other institutions.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Work/Life balance. Lots of vacation days and holidays including the week between Christmas and New Year's Day. Summers off if you are a professor (unless you elect to teach summer school). Free education for you and your immediate family.
cons: Salaries are not competitive with other universities for the same positions and far below private industry. Very little camaraderie. Cut-throat atmosphere. Constant turnover and reorganization. Budgets are tight for any extras such as attending professional conferences, hosting an event or even getting a new computer.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Free tuition as a grad assistant. The school is relatively small so you can be heard and seen when you need the attention of the "higher ups"
cons: Not the most prestigious institution out there. It's a school, so the individuals who should be fired are usually allowed to stay on, and continue to make life difficult for those who are genuinely trying their best. Also being a non profit institution, you can't expect too much in the way of salary.

review_title: Time well spent for developing a career, enjoying a fabulous work-life balance and great support from managers.
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: The people are all devoted to the students and creating an opportune learning environment from the top-down and the bottom-up.
cons: They experienced decreased enrollment, tuition increases, and leadership changes and that created conflict and instability for students and employees alike.

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The job allowed med to learn a lot about working in an academic and administrative facility. Kind supervisors and managers. Large diversity of students and co-workers to work with. Management is understand of employees' situation and difficulties.
cons: Office politics. When managers or advisors have their own personal issues with each other, the wrath falls to us. Difficult to please both sides if they have their own personal problems.

job_title: Computer Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Working with Pace as a student is really convenient because all of the managers know that as students your schedule needs to be flexible enough to accommodate your classes and they work with you. I made some of my best friends via my coworkers who were also students.
cons: Most positions pay minimum wage this is offset if you are under Federal Work Study since there wont be any taxes taken out of your pay.

job_title: Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Nice place to work.  Plenty of academic freedom.  I get along well with both faculty and staff.
cons: Health insurance is very expensive.  Salaries can be on the lower side, especially depending upon the Department.  I am content with my salary.  Some faculty and staff are paid at a much higher rate than others.  Work-life balance is a struggle; lots of work on the tenure track.

job_title: Anonymous in New York, NY
pros: Certain departments are great to work with and try to actually help students.
cons: Upper Management do not care about you. Pay is worse, incentives awful and high turnover in certain departments based on awful management styles. Human Resources dept is a joke.

review_title: My first part time job on campus
job_title: Student Assistant in White Plains, NY
pros: Was a part time job on-campus. Had a lot of self time to study and work. Not too demanding. A good thing was boss was very motivating and supportive. He used to set a good example for us. Learnt a lot from him.
cons: No challenges, no growth potential.

job_title: Staff Associate in Oradell, NJ
pros: A good opportunity to gain professional office experience. Learn how to work in high pressure and fast paced environment. Also, built customer service skills by dealing with students, faculty, and parents.
cons: There is a lack of support for growth and development within the University. Salary does not equally reflect amount of responsibilities.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in White Plains, NY
pros: Great place to work serving the students and the community with free legal services. The law school is a small community of dedicated people in all departments helping and looking out for one another. Many people work here for many years and that says a lot.
cons: Higher salaries are always welcome with better benefits.

review_title: So-so, but could have been better...
job_title: Registrar Associate in New York, NY
pros:
Convenient location; easy to get to by train.
Located in a good area (downtown) with tons of shops and restaurant snearby.
Nice, caring bosses.
Bosses will work around your schedule.
Bosses are pretty easy-going (and they'll do stuff like buy you lunch).
Easy to get a job here.
Good food.
cons:
Pay and benefits could be better.
No overtime.
Co-workers can be rude sometimes.
Lunch break is a bit too short.

job_title: Lab Tech in New York, NY
pros: Working at Pace University as a laboratory technician enhanced and supplemented my education. The professors in the department are great.
cons: Some of the laboratory technicians do not pull their weight. However, I believe this problem has been resolved with new management.

job_title: Admissions in New York, NY
pros:
Pay for your undergraduate education

Friendly co-workers

Many holidays
cons:
Salary is abysmal for a higher education institution
Managers are non supportive
Long hours, no compensation
High turn over rate

job_title: Student Aide in New York, NY
pros: flexible schedule, free food & you usually get to know about things going on in the university before the other kids.
cons: University bureaucracy,  you feel more like staff than a student, you work and go to school in the same building, no networking opportunities, they kick you out after you graduate, doesn't look super great on a resume.

job_title: Note Taker in New York, NY
pros: I really like it. They are really nice here and want to help you prosper and do well in your position.
cons: I do not have any as of now everyone is nice about my work and always supports you.

job_title: Adjunct Professor in New York, NY
pros: Can be a good short-term in-between teaching job to gain experience and move onto a better department at another University.
cons: The Art Department has a toxic, back-biting culture among its full time faculty.  If you happen to get caught in their crossfire, it can feel like you've  entered into an alter-reality of gas lighting and scapegoating. A strange environment enveloped in secretive, cruel behavior. The adjunct union is unfortunately quite weak at Pace, and the pay is the lowest I have received as an adjunct in NYC.

review_title: Good for the most part, just a few minor issues.
job_title: Seidenberg Development Team in New York, NY
pros: The pay is good($13 an hour), everyone there is nice and motivated, and I feel that I am learning a lot by being involved in projects.
cons: Management is not always available, and we aren't given enough direction on projects as a result.

review_title: Free Tuition but Low Salaries & Little Room for Advancement
job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY
pros: Tuition Remission for self/employee, spouse and college-age kids
cons:
Salaries are not competitive with other universities for the same job.  
Internal politics is rampant.   Little opportunity for advancement.  Pace prefers to go outside and hire expensive management consultants vs looking within to staff and faculty members who could offer better advice/recommendations/strategy.

job_title: Faculty in New York, NY
pros: Love the people and the students
cons: Commuting downtown is difficult and expensive.

review_title: Good experience going on..hope for the best to go
job_title: in New York, NY
pros: Very helpful people and prompt.guide correctly and encourage for better  career and studies. Promotes for various activities on campus to learn and participate
cons: I could not find any of the cons till now..other than some difficulty in getting an on campus job as students are more and jobs limited

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: You work fairly autonomous.
cons: Management is a bit all over the place.

job_title: Human Resources Coordinator in Brooklyn, NY
pros: There are a lot you could learn.  There are some amazing people that work there.
cons: a bit bias toward employees who did not attend school at Pace.  They are more willing to work with their alumni.

job_title: Pace Graduate Assistantship in New York, NY
pros: As the graduate assistant in the Publishing department, I was always treated well. Also, 32 of 36 hours of my tuition were paid for. I also received a stipend.
cons: I wish that the assistantship could have lasted throughout my entire time at Pace as a student.

job_title: Office Assistant in New York, NY
pros: The people are very nice
cons: There are not enough reps for the students so during the time of year where students need to speak to office reps they wait hours and we get slammed.

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Excellent place to get an education.
cons: Salaries are too low.  Overtime not paid. Only comp options

job_title: Director in New York, NY
pros: Passionate professionals helping students succeed. Good work/life balance.
cons: Typical academic focus on discussion and debate which leads to delayed or no decisions. Compensation not up to par for a NYC university.

job_title: Student Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Flexible schedule, very accommodating to student workers
cons: There is a lot of red tape within the university system, it took me almost 3 months to get my first paycheck because of an error with my address and the amount of time it took payroll to process my checks.

review_title: Great opportunities to grow and work together.
job_title: Pace Graduate Assistantship in New York, NY
pros: Numerous events are organized and I can network and make more connections and also I get to work on my skills which will help me for my career
cons: Always need to be on my toes because I have to have the required skills

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Was a friendly and harmonious place to work. There was mutual cooperation and trust. Paid vacations include personal, Christmas thru New Years, and summer Fridays.
cons: New management is not transparent. Suddenly lots of politics. Budgets are constant source of concern. Staff is not recognized properly for contributions.

job_title: Director in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Students and Colleagues are wonderful. Overall benefits is good. Flexible work schedules. Leadership. Service learning culture and focus on diversity is present.
cons: Maternity leave is minimal for birth parent and non-existent for partners. Encourage greater diversity in policies and benefits for employees with children.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
Most individuals are well-meaning and friendly.
Location in FiDi is very convenient.
cons:
At the time, the University had many financial and administrative problems, but proposed solutions all involved finger pointing and someone else needing to change.
Salaries were low compared to other institutions in the area.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Pleasantville, NY
pros: Decent Benefits, Work from home, Decent work life balance. Unlimited Sick Days
cons: Low Pay, Poor lack of direction depending on department. High turn over rate. Pace is a stepping stone to another University.

job_title: Manager in New York, NY
pros:
Great company culture 
Good learning environment 
Nice and motivated people
You will learn a lot working here because of the fast paced environment
cons: The atmosphere can be really laid back and boring during times when there are school breaks so definitely be aware of that

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: As a student, you have a good opportunity to have contacts with professors and other staff as well as the students.
cons: A lot, I seriously mean a lot of work!!

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in New York, NY
pros: It is fun to work here. Great work-life balance, no big stress. They pay you 6 credits per semester, which is really helpful.
cons: I see no cons, the Professor I work for is really helpful to me and tasks are manageable.

review_title: ELI Program Assistant - Great student experience
job_title: ELI Program Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Great opportunities to work in an academic environment and practice your business admin skills; great managers who care about students and be supportive about what they do professionally and personally.
cons: Not much cons I could think of.
